case_metadata.title: Case 9453: 73-Year-Old Male with Epigastric Pain and Subsequent Respiratory Complications Post-Surgery

source.pages: Discussion By Dr. Hugh Cabot, Case 9453, Further Discussion, Necropsy Findings

social_history.alcohol_use: Good habits mentioned, implying no excessive alcohol use
social_history.tobacco_use: Not mentioned, likely non-smoker given 'good habits'

medical_history.past_medical_conditions: Dyspnea on exertion, occasional sharp precordial pain, urgency and frequency of urination five years ago, lessened urinary stream recently, epigastric pain for eight years with attacks every 3-4 months lasting 5-6 weeks. Constipation.

surgical_history.previous_surgeries: None mentioned prior to current admission

turn_1.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_1.message: Alright, let's discuss Case 9453. This is a 73-year-old American man, formerly a deep-sea fisherman, who came to us from the Out-Patient Department on August 22nd, 1923.
turn_1.source_reference: Case 9453: 'An American of seventy-three, formerly a deep-sea fisherman, was sent from the Out-Patient Department August 22, 1923...'

turn_2.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_2.message: He's complaining of pain in the epigastrium for eight years.  His mother died of tuberculosis, and a brother of 'stone cutters' consumption'. Another brother is possibly ill with the same.
turn_2.intention: Presenting family history and chief complaint.
turn_2.source_reference: Case 9453: 'complaining of pain in the epigastrium of eight years' duration. F. H. His mother died of tuberculosis, one brother of 'stone cutters' consumption.' Another brother was now ill, possibly with the same disease.'

turn_3.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_3.timestamp: Immediately after turn_2, Patient History continued.
turn_3.message: He says his habits are good.  Past medical history - he was healthy until this gastric trouble started eight years ago. Since then, he’s had dyspnea on exertion and occasional precordial pain.  Five years ago, urinary urgency and frequency, and recently, a weaker urinary stream.
turn_3.intention: Presenting past medical and social history.
turn_3.context: Continuing patient's history, focusing on past illnesses.
turn_3.source_reference: Case 9453: 'Habits. Good. P. H. He was strong, healthy and active until the beginning of his gastric trouble eight years ago, Since the onset of this illness he had had dyspnea on exertion...Recently the stream had lessened in caliber and force.'

turn_4.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_4.message: For eight years he's had these attacks, similar to this one, every three or four months, lasting five or six weeks.  Between attacks, he feels well.  He’s also been quite constipated since this started.
turn_4.intention: Describing the chronic nature of the patient's illness.
turn_4.context: Detailing the episodic pattern of the symptoms.
turn_4.source_reference: Case 9453: 'P. I. For eight years he had had attacks similar to the present one, occurring every three or four months and lasting five or six weeks. Between the attacks he had felt well. Since the beginning of this trouble his bowels had been Very constipated.'

turn_5.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_5.timestamp: Immediately after turn_4, Current Episode Details
turn_5.message: Six weeks ago, this current episode began with epigastric pain after eating, sometimes relieved by food or soda. It’s constant, dull, often keeps him up at night, sometimes sharp and radiating to the shoulders. He's nauseous, vomiting almost everything, even coffee-ground material recently.  Lost about thirty pounds and strength. Bowels haven’t moved for days and troubled by gas.
turn_5.intention: Detailing the acute symptoms and severity of the current episode.
turn_5.context: Explaining the progression and worsening of symptoms leading to admission.
turn_5.source_reference: Case 9453: 'Six weeks before admission he began to have epigastric pain...vomiting almost everything he ate. Two weeks ago and again the day before admission he vomited coffee ground material...bowels had not moved for days.'

turn_6.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_6.timestamp: Immediately after turn_5, Out-Patient Department Records from 1915
turn_6.message: Looking back at records from 1915, he had a similar attack then, lasting four months, with gastric distress and sharp epigastric pain after eating, relieved by food or vomiting.  He had gas, occasional vomiting, and lost 13.5 pounds back then. Examination showed spasm in the right upper rectus.
turn_6.intention: Referencing past medical records for context and comparison.
turn_6.context: Providing historical perspective on the recurring nature of the illness.
turn_6.source_reference: Case 9453: 'Records of the Out-Patient Department May 21, 1915. showed a history of the first attack, then of four months' duration...Examination showed spasm of the right upper rectus.'

turn_7.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_7.message: Stomach contents in 1915 showed free HCl, guaiac negative, and the test meal had blood clots, free HCl 0.31%, total acid 0.4%. By June 1915, he was weaker, knee-jerks increased, Romberg positive.
turn_7.intention: Presenting historical lab and neurological findings.
turn_7.context: Detailing specific findings from the previous episode.
turn_7.source_reference: Case 9453: 'May 27, 1915, the fasting contents of the stomach showed free HC1, guaiac negative; test meal, a few blood clots, free HC1 0.31%, total acid 0.4%. June 8, 1915, he was weaker, knee-jerks increased, Romberg positive.'

turn_8.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_8.timestamp: Immediately after turn_7, Physical Examination on Current Admission
turn_8.message: On physical exam now, evidence of weight loss, poor teeth, moderate pyorrhea. Lungs normal. Heart apex impulse in the fifth space, A2 accentuated, soft systolic murmur at the apex. Radials slightly palpable. BP 180/88. Abdomen - rigidity and spasm in the right upper quadrant, tenderness there and down the midline. Possible mass felt in the area of spasm. Genitals, extremities, pupils, reflexes normal otherwise.
turn_8.context: Presenting the patient's condition upon admission.
turn_8.source_reference: Case 9453: 'P. E. Evidence of loss of weight. Teeth poor. Moderate pyorrhea. Lungs normal. Apex impulse of the heart...Abdomen. Definite rigidity and spasm in the right upper quadrant...'

turn_9.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_9.message: Pre-op chart unremarkable, urine cloudy and alkaline once, otherwise negative. Blood not recorded, Wassermann negative. X-ray showed stomach emptying normally, active peristalsis suggesting irritation, questionable sphincter regularity, and irregular filling of the first part of the duodenum with tenderness.
turn_9.context: Detailing results of urine, serology and X-ray before surgery.
turn_9.source_reference: Case 9453: 'Before operation chart not remarkable, urine cloudy and alkaline at the single examination, otherwise negative, blood not recorded, Wassermann negative. X-ray. Stomach empty in normal time...First portion of duodenum constantly irregular in filling. Tenderness in this region.'

turn_10.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_10.message: He had an operation on August 25th.  The next day, he was generally okay, but started vomiting and continued for two days.
turn_10.source_reference: Case 9453: 'August 25 operation was done. Next day the general condition was good, but the patient vomited and continued to vomit during the next two days.'

turn_11.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_11.message: By August 28th, his temperature rose to 102.2°, pulse to 136, respirations to 32.  Purulent sputum, and râles were heard in his lungs. He worsened, became dyspneic and cyanotic, lungs filled with râles.
turn_11.intention: Describing the worsening respiratory condition post-surgery.
turn_11.source_reference: Case 9453: 'August 28 the temperature rose to 102.2°, the pulse to 136, the respirations to 32. There was purulent sputum, and râles were heard. The patient became worse, grew dyspneic and cyanotic ; the lungs filled with râles.'

turn_13.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_13.message: So, the dyspnea and precordial pain in his history certainly suggested angina, pointing to arteriosclerosis. The epigastric pain was different and suggestive of duodenal ulcer, especially given the 1915 findings, though maybe insufficient for a definitive diagnosis then. Increased knee-jerks and Romberg in 1915 are harder to explain, perhaps arteriosclerotic changes in the nervous system?
turn_13.intention: Analyzing patient's history and symptoms to reach a pre-operative diagnosis.
turn_13.context: Interpreting symptoms in light of possible underlying conditions.
turn_13.source_reference: Discussion By Dr. Hugh Cabot: 'The description of this man's present illness seems to coincide rather strikingly with the only suggestive fact in his previous history: namely, the dyspnea on exertion and the precordial pain...It is not easy to account for his other symptoms, namely increased knee-jerks and positive Romberg, except upon the assumption of arteriosclerotic changes in the nervous system.'

turn_14.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_14.message: It's surprising he lived this long if his 1915 condition was as described.  These attacks every few months must have been short, with good recovery in between. This current attack is different though, pain is constant, less relieved by food or soda.
turn_14.intention: Reflecting on the chronicity and progression of the illness.
turn_14.context: Analyzing the changing nature of symptoms over time.
turn_14.source_reference: Discussion By Dr. Hugh Cabot: 'It is on the whole a little surprising that he has continued to live as long as he has if one takes their description of his condition in 1915 at its face value...It is noticeable that the history of the present attack is slightly different from the first one in that the pain is constant and but partially relieved either by food or by soda.'

turn_15.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_15.timestamp: Discussion of Physical Exam and Investigations
turn_15.message: Physical exam suggests arteriosclerosis, though no clear hypertrophy or dilatation of the heart.  Blood pressure is high.  Possible arteriosclerotic nephritis, though not confirmed.  We can assume a stomach or duodenal lesion causing his symptoms.  Likely the same lesion for eight years, so primary cancer is less likely, but secondary cancer on chronic ulcer is possible.
turn_15.intention: Integrating physical exam and investigation findings into the diagnostic process.
turn_15.context: Formulating a differential diagnosis based on available evidence.
turn_15.source_reference: Discussion By Dr. Hugh Cabot: 'The physical examination suggests arteriosclerosis, though we have no positive evidence of hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart. His blood pressure is definitely above normal...We shall I think be justified in assuming that he has a lesion of the stomach or duodenum, and that this accounts for the symptoms of his present attack.'

turn_16.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_16.message: X-ray points to a duodenal lesion, typical of chronic ulcer.  Pyloric sphincter description raises question of stomach and duodenum lesion, but that's unlikely.  Probably safe to exclude secondary malignancy to ulcer in this region. So, I'm leaning towards chronic duodenal ulcer.
turn_16.intention: Reaching a pre-operative diagnosis based on X-ray findings.
turn_16.context: Narrowing down the diagnosis to chronic duodenal ulcer.
turn_16.source_reference: Discussion By Dr. Hugh Cabot: 'The x-ray examination seems to be positive as to a lesion of the duodenum quite typical of a chronic ulcer...In this region we are pretty safe in excluding malignant disease secondary to ulcer, and I therefore cannot avoid the diagnosis of chronic duodenal ulcer.'

turn_17.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_17.timestamp: Discussion of Treatment and Operative Approach
turn_17.message: Treatment-wise, diet might not be enough for this chronic, indurated ulcer. In a younger man, operation is clear.  Here, age and arteriosclerosis make him a risk.  But operation might still be best if he understands the risks, though diet could be tried. I’d advise operation cautiously. For surgery, prolonged ether anesthesia is risky. Spinal anesthesia too dangerous for his age. I prefer local infiltration, maybe short gas and oxygen if needed. Local anesthesia alone can work well.
turn_17.intention: Discussing treatment options and surgical strategy.
turn_17.context: Considering risks and benefits of surgery in an elderly patient with comorbidities.
turn_17.source_reference: Discussion By Dr. Hugh Cabot: 'In regard to treatment, this is not the sort of lesion likely to be benefited by dietetic measures, since it is clearly a chronic ulcer of the indurated type...In this case one might properly hesitate to advise operation, but simply on the ground that his age and probable arteriosclerosis make him a poor risk...My own choice in such cases has been local anesthesia by infiltration and then a short general anesthesia with gas and oxygen if the lesion proved unmanageable under local.'

turn_18.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_18.message: My pre-operative diagnoses are: Chronic duodenal ulcer and Arteriosclerosis.
turn_18.context: Concluding the diagnostic discussion before surgery.
turn_18.source_reference: DR. CABOT'S PRE-OPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 'Chronic duodenal ulcer. Arteriosclerosis.'

turn_19.speaker: Surgeon A
turn_19.message: (Surgeon's Notes) Made a 20 cm right rectus incision. Used block anesthesia with procaine near the lumbar vertebra and local novocain infiltration. Peritoneum opened without issue. Found an ulcer in an indurated area of the first duodenum. Omentum adherent, gall-bladder negative. Jejunum mobilized, mesocolon hole made, edges sutured to stomach. Gastro-enterostomy performed. Patient complained with mesentery traction, parietal peritoneum seemed anesthetic, snaps painless, closure difficult due to straining. Patient seemed okay at the end.
turn_19.intention: Documenting the surgical procedure and findings.
turn_19.source_reference: Operation: 'Twenty cm. right rectus incision...Exploration revealed an ulcer in an indurated area in the first portion of the duodenum...ordinary gastro-enterostomy was done...The patient complained of discomfort when traction was made on the mesentery.'

turn_20.speaker: Surgeon A
turn_20.message: (Surgeon's Notes) In the first inch of the duodenum from the pylorus, marked thinning and narrowing. No further exploration. Omentum adhesion in lower right quadrant made stomach turning difficult, so it was tied and cut to relieve tension.
turn_20.context: Additional notes on surgical findings and maneuvers.
turn_20.source_reference: Surgeon's Notes: 'In the first portion of the duodenum extending from the pylorus downward for one inch there was marked thinning and narrowing of the duodenum...The only unusual fact was that the omentum was adherent in the lower right quadrant...'

turn_21.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_21.message: The block anesthesia seems to have worked well. Wound closure difficulty is common with local anesthesia and gas. Duodenal ulcer diagnosis confirmed surgically, gastro-enterostomy was the right move. Good decision not to touch the ulcer.
turn_21.intention: Reviewing the surgical procedure and confirming its appropriateness.
turn_21.context: Post-operative assessment of the surgery itself.
turn_21.source_reference: Further Discussion: 'The block anesthesia which they elected to use seems to have worked pretty satisfactorily...The evidence that the lesion was in fact a chronic ulcer of the duodenum seemed satisfactory and the indication for a gastro-enterostomy clear. I think they were well advised in this case not to make any attack upon the ulcer.'

turn_22.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_22.message: Post-operative course strongly suggests respiratory infection causing death.  Purulent bronchitis or bronchopneumonia, we can't say for sure without necropsy.  No reason to suspect abdominal infection.
turn_22.intention: Hypothesizing the cause of post-operative death.
turn_22.source_reference: Further Discussion: 'The history after operation strongly suggests that his death was due to a respiratory infection such as is not uncommon in these patients...I see no reason for assuming that there was any important infection below the diaphragm.'

turn_23.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_23.message: Necropsy should show arteriosclerosis, duodenal ulcer, heart hypertrophy and dilatation, coronary sclerosis, myocardial degeneration, maybe arteriosclerotic nephritis, purulent bronchitis, possibly bronchopneumonia.
turn_23.context: Formulating expectations for the post-mortem examination.
turn_23.source_reference: Further Discussion: 'Necropsy should show arteriosclerosis, ulcer of the duodenum, hypertrophy, and dilatation of the heart, probably definite coronary sclerosis with areas of myocardial degeneration, possibly arteriosclerotic nephritis, purulent bronchitis, possibly bronchopneumonia.'

turn_24.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_24.message: We weren't allowed to examine the head. Abdominal wall incision was 16 cm, closed. Peritoneal cavity, appendix, esophagus negative. Gastro-jejunal anastomosis patent and good. Stomach mucosa flat but negative. Duodenal ulcer in the posterior wall, 1.5cm by 12mm, rounded margins, smooth base over pancreas, adhesions in lesser omentum. Small intestine negative. Large intestine had sigmoid diverticula and rectal papillomata. Mesenteric and retroperitoneal glands negative.
turn_24.intention: Reporting macroscopic findings of the necropsy.
turn_24.source_reference: Necropsy Findings: 'In the anterior abdominal wall there was a linear operation wound 16 cm. long closed with sutures...The pyloric ridge formed the upper margin of a loss of substance in the posterior wall of the duodenum 1½ cm. by 12 mm...The large intestine shewed several small intact diverticula in the sigmoid region, and in the region of the rectum there were two very small papillomata.'

turn_25.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_25.message: Small amount of fibrinopurulent fluid in each pleural cavity, no adhesions. Lung apices negative. Upper lobes pale, spongy, thin reddish frothy fluid. Lower lobes dark red, spongy to leathery, with pneumonia foci, some subpleural, pleura coated with fibrinopurulent material.
turn_25.intention: Reporting necropsy findings in the pleural cavities and lungs.
turn_25.context: Describing respiratory pathology found at necropsy.
turn_25.source_reference: Necropsy Findings: 'In each pleural cavity there was a small amount of fibrinopurulent semi-fluid material...The tissue of the lower lobes was dark red, and spongy to a little leathery. In each lower lobe about midway there were several smaller and larger foci of pneumonia...'

turn_26.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_26.message: Heart weighed 400 grams, slightly enlarged. Myocardium brown-red, lax to soft. Cavities slightly dilated. Valves negative. Coronaries showed slight to moderate arteriosclerosis, no lumen narrowing. Aorta and great branches showed marked fibrous and fibrocalcareous sclerosis, capacious.
turn_26.intention: Reporting necropsy findings of the heart and major vessels.
turn_26.source_reference: Necropsy Findings: 'The heart weighed 400 grams, slightly enlarged...The coronaries were free but showed a slight to moderate amount of arteriosclerosis...The aorta and great branches showed marked fibrous and fibrocalcareous sclerosis, and were rather capacious.'

turn_27.speaker: Dr. Richardson
turn_27.message: Spleen rather small and soft. Kidneys combined 213 grams, small. Capsules stripped, pale brown-red surfaces with depressions. Tissue slightly more consistent, vessel cut ends prominent. Markings visible, cortex 3-5mm.  Arteriosclerotic degeneration of kidneys, not full nephritis.
turn_27.intention: Reporting necropsy findings of the spleen and kidneys.
turn_27.source_reference: Necropsy Findings: 'The spleen was rather small and the tissue somewhat soft. The combined weight of the kidneys was 213 grams, rather small...The whole picture was that of arteriosclerotic degeneration of the kidneys, not of sufficient extent to be called arteriosclerotic nephritis.'

turn_28.speaker: Dr. Cabot
turn_28.message: Necropsy findings match what we expected.  The appendix being normal is a bit odd given the described adhesions.
turn_28.intention: Concluding remarks on the necropsy findings and discrepancies.
turn_28.context: Final assessment and minor inconsistencies noted.
turn_28.source_reference: NOTE BY DR. CABOT: 'The necropsy findings coincide closely with what one would have expected. The statement that the appendix is normal is a little hard to reconcile with the adhesions which they describe.'

presentation.chief_complaint: Epigastric pain of eight years duration, worsening in current episode.
presentation.history_of_present_illness: Recurrent epigastric pain for eight years, with exacerbations every 3-4 months. Current episode started six weeks prior to admission, with constant pain after eating, nausea, vomiting (including coffee-ground emesis), weight loss, and constipation.
presentation.physical_exam: Evidence of weight loss, poor dentition, pyorrhea, normal lungs, cardiac murmur and accentuated A2, elevated blood pressure (180/88), right upper quadrant abdominal rigidity and tenderness, possible mass.

laboratory_data.value: Free HCl present, guaiac negative, blood clots, free HCl 0.31%, total acid 0.4%

imaging.description: Stomach empty in normal time, active peristalsis, questionable sphincter regularity, irregular filling of first portion of duodenum, tenderness in duodenal region.

procedures.description: Surgical anastomosis between stomach and jejunum performed for duodenal ulcer.
Procaine injection near lumbar vertebra and local novocain infiltration used for anesthesia during surgery.

timeline_events.event: Onset of epigastric pain and gastric issues.

timeline_events.time: 8 years prior to admission, recurring every 3-4 months
timeline_events.event: Attacks of epigastric pain lasting 5-6 weeks.
Onset of urinary urgency and frequency.
Current episode of epigastric pain begins, worsening symptoms, vomiting, weight loss.
Patient sent from Out-Patient Department for admission.
Fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, purulent sputum, râles in lungs, dyspnea, cyanosis.

final_diagnoses: Dr. Cabot's Diagnosis: Ulcer of duodenum, Arteriosclerosis, Hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart, Probably definite coronary sclerosis with areas of myocarditis and degeneration, Probably arteriosclerotic nephritis, Purulent bronchitis, Possibly bronchopneumonia.

Anatomical Diagnosis (Necropsy): Ulcer of the duodenum (Primary Fatal Lesion), Focal pneumonia of the lower lobes of the lungs, Fibrinopurulent pleuritis, Acute degeneration of the myocardium, Soft spleen, Arteriosclerosis, Arteriosclerotic degeneration of the kidneys, Hypertrophy and dilatation of the heart, Edema of the lungs (Secondary or Terminal Lesions)
